quote: In thy faint slumbers by thee have watched, and heard thee murmur tales of iron wars, speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed, cry "Courage!
My lord, cheer up your spirits; our foes are nigh, and this soft courage makes your followers faint.
This may plant courage in their quailing breasts, for yet is hope of life and victory.
Thy daemon--that thy spirit which keeps thee--is noble, courageous, high, unmatchable, where Caesar's is not.
Thy life is dear, for all that life can rate worth name of life in thee hath estimate: youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all that happiness and prime can happy call.
play: (All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 68)

quote: Could find in my heart to disgrace my man's apparel and to cry like a woman, but must comfort the weaker vessel, as doublet and hose ought to show itself courageous to petticoat.

But, worthy Hector, she is a theme of honor and renown, spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds, whose present courage may beat down our foes, and fame in time to come canonize us; for presume brave Hector would not lose so rich advantage of a promised glory as smiles upon the forehead of this action for the wide world's revenue.

I'll reconcile me to Polixenes, new woo my queen, recall the good Camillo, whom proclaim a man of truth, of mercy; for, being transported by my jealousies to bloody thoughts and to revenge, chose camillo for the minister to poison my friend Polixenes, which had been done but that the good mind of Camillo tardied my swift command, though with death and with reward did threaten and encourage him, not doing it and being done.
